risk_factor_risk_rating Future income – Alternative land uses are unlikely to occur in the future; col_2 Low; campo_verde_project The risk that alternative land uses will occur in the future is mitigated in several ways: The project is on freehold land 1. owned by the project developer, SFM- BAM. This has enabled the project management to take a long- term perspective on the underlying business opportunity. The pre-project land use and the 2. surrounding area land use support little economic activity, apart from low-density cattle grazing and subsistence agriculture. Without the project activities providing capital investment, the degraded state of the land has prevented alternative land uses such as large-scale agriculture. The degraded land will continue to prevent such alternatives from being implemented in the future. Reforestation is a long-term activity 3. in which the ‘inventory’ accrues value overtime as the trees grow. Although it is possible that land opportunity costs will rise in the surrounding areas (though unlikely, see point 2 above), this will be offset by the rising economic value of trees (in terms of timber value) and carbon on the project land over time.

findings_from_review_on_field_audit The project initiated land restoration activities because land use of project area was degraded pasture for many years, so it has degraded conditions. Almost no soil productivity, poor physical and chemical characteristics of soil, lack of water sources and low biodiversity in the area described the initial conditions. The project proponent started a rehabilitation program with research institutions and environmental NGOs to recuperate soil conditions before installation of timber plantations. There were several cycles of planting Guaba (Inga spp.) unsuccessfully. Guaba in now part of all plantations models; it is planted in combinations with all timber species. The project proponent has demonstrated its interest in establishing timber plantations in the long term and making overall improvements to environmental conditions in project area. At the moment, project area has timber species that will be harvested in intervals between 20 and 30 years, depending on growth assumptions, but the project proponent is monitoring growth actual to have real time information about on-site conditions. The project proponent states in PD that project area will be dedicated to permanent plantation management. The auditor has verified this information through interviews with local stakeholders.

auditor(s) Campbell Moore; qualifications Carbon Expert with Rainforest Alliance. Campbell has experience on both the technical and policy sides of REDD+. Campbell's recent professional experience includes consulting work for GIZ Philippines performing carbon stock assessments of different forest types, including agroforestry and plantation systems, as well as work centered on reforestation in Sri Lanka for the Environmental Leadership and Training Initiative. He additionally has worked for Climate Focus on LULUCF policy issues. From 2009-2011 Campbell pursued his Master of Forestry from the Yale University School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. During this time period he concentrated heavily on REDD+. This period included a variety of forestry projects including developing a management plan for Connecticut forest preserve, planning timber sales in a New England hardwood forest, and designing and modelling carbon sequestration potential of agroforestry systems for the Nature Conservancy’s Global Climate Team. Prior to his time at Yale, Campbell worked in The Gambia for over two years as a Peace Corps Volunteer designing and implementing a wide variety of forestry, agroforestry, and agricultural projects. In addition to his Master of Forestry degree, he holds a M.A. in Environmental Studies from St. Mary’s College. Campbell is fluent in Pulaar and Wolof and has experience with Spanish.

campo_verde_project R eforestation is a long-term activity and is unique in that the value of “inventory” accrues the longer the trees are in the ground. Many of the trees in the Campo Verde project have been planted on a 30 year rotation and revenues are to be generated both by timber and carbon. Land opportunity costs may rise in the surrounding areas (though unlikely, see point 2 above), but this will be offset by the rising economic value of trees (in terms of timber value) and carbon on the project land over time.

findings_from_verification_field_audit Sampling design and stratification; col_2 The project proponent has not installed new plantation areas, so new stratification has not been necessary. The stratification was completed in the beginning of the project; the stratum (stand) is defined by species and stand model of the plantation, because all other conditions are similar (soils, climate, land use) The project proponent has installed 65 permanent plots (35 x 35m) for monitoring changes of carbon stocks. Seven permanent plots were visited during field work and the auditor verified plot locations, maps, measurements (DBH, DAC) and species. The measurements were compared with database and forms from the project; all information was found to be in conformance. Equation 55, 56 and 57 (AR-AM0003 v04) were used to calculate the number of plots, sampling error is less than 10%. The permanent plots are measured before the verification process begins and are used to inform the monitoring report.

Project Proponent: Distribution of PSPs in field follows grid method per stratum with Software Arc GIS Arc Map v.10, where you upload the shape file with the cover of the plantation. After that, with the tool “Create Fishnet” introducing dimensions 35x35 (the size of the plot), we chose only squares intersected with plantation area and are totally contained within any stratum. With tool “Feature to point”, we create the centroid of each square and with the tool “Add XY coordinates” we export the four coordinates to Excel for its numbering. With that, we have completed the layout of plots. Having defined the amount of PSP per stratum (with WINROCK tool), we use the Excel function “Aleatorio.entre (numero inferior. numero superior), selecting randomly the number of plots in the range, adding more plots for safety reasons. Each centroid will be the starting point of the plot. Previously, the amount of plots per stratum was established with the support of Winrock Terrestrial Sampling Calculator Tool, that helps to determine based on level of error; confidence level and total number of planted hectares (in all VCS area and per stratum), calculating previously the average of CO2 per hectare and the standard deviation of the same units. With all this information, the Winrock tool calculates the number of plots per stratum.; audit_team_clarify_the_method_used_to_determine_the_sample_plots_distribution_in_the_field A udit Team An explanation was included in the MR, regarding the method used to determine the sample plots distribution in the field

findings_from_verification_field_audit During the verification site visit, the auditor verified project boundaries, visited seven plots where independent measurements of DBH, DAC, and height were taken in 50% of plantation trees. The results were reviewed in comparison with the project proponents plot measurement data and found to be reasonable. Other on-site verification activities included: verification of plot locations using GPS, verification of plot size with tape measures, plots identification, and verification of strata/stand models in project area. No inconsistencies or errors were found, the project proponent has implemented monitoring activities according to procedures identified in the validated PD. The auditor verified the Monitoring Plan against AR-AM0003 version 04.

findings_from_verification_field_audit In this verification period, the project proponent has not installed new plantation areas, so the sampling plan was implemented according to the validated PD; as a result a new calculation was not necessary. At the beginning of the project, a sampling intensity of 65 sample plots was calculated using Equation 55, 56, 57 (AR-AM0003 v04). The project proponent applied a 95% confidence level to estimate number of sample plots, at 20% of error. Although the PD (section 10.3.2.2.) describes using circular plots, when plots were installed the design changed to use of square plots, and all procedures discuss square plots. In the Monitoring Report (section on Stratification and Sampling), the project proponent mentions that there are two types of plots: in plantation areas the fixed size is 35m by 35m; and 50m by 50m in size for the natural regeneration areas. ArcGIS (and “Create Random Points” tool) was used to determine the locations of plots.

findings_from_verification_field_audit T T The project proponent estimates emissions reductions from carbon sequestration in the plantation area using the allometric equation method and measurement of relevant parameters in the 65 permanent sampling plots established. he proponent uses a combination of well regarded allometric equations from the scientific literature (the Chave 2005 equations) and allometric equations developed by the proponent for trees less than 5cm DBH, and for Guaba (Inga edulis) trees. The proponent has shown the procedure followed to obtain its own formula (Ecuation Guaba 1 y 2.xls): - First Equation Guaba: 2.12 cm to 15.35 cm DAC (diameter taken at the base of the plant), Equ 1= -0.824+0.182*(DAC2), R2 =0.95 - Second Equation Guaba: 15.35cm to 25.5cm DAC, Equ 2=0.219+(DAC2). The auditor has reviewed the calculation of project emission reductions in the document Calculos.xls, and confirmed the accuracy of these calculations and that they follow the validated PD Monitoring plan and methodology. he formulas and default values used in all calculations are correct according to the methodology, AR-AM0003 v04. The proponent estimates the tCO2 for the period 2010-2012, subtracting total project emissions, less GHG removlas by sinks in the baseline scenario (2012), minus the already credited carbon sequestration in the previous monitoring period. This results in a total net emission reduction of -eq. The calculations are shown in a transparent form, and the auditor was able to clearly trace the methodological logic 34,452.76 tCO2 through the spreadsheet.

findings_from_verification_field_audit During the field verification work, the auditor found that inventory techniques used to calculate net removals followed the procedures established by the project proponent in the validated PD. Woody trees were measured for DBH and height with a DBH tape and telescopic rule respectively. In case of Guaba, it was measured in DAC (diameter in base of stem). In both other woody trees and Guaba, the point of measurement is marked on stems for the next verification period. The plots measured during the verification process are in conformance with all archiving and database requirements, and all have been recorded are found to be accurate. Information is reviewed by field staff and then stored in electronic files; hardcopies are archived in a secure place. Inventory techniques have been implemented according to the monitoring plan and procedures.

findings_from_verification_field_audit Monitoring of project implementation: Forest establishment and management; col_2 The proponent has demonstrated that forest establishment has been monitored, and all information about site preparation, planting activities has been verified in electronic files and forms. The original plantation area was established in 2001, and in this verification the proponent continued with forest establishment activities. This involved continuing with plantation activities in the remaining unplanted area. Each forest management unit (FMU) has a permanent monitoring procedure for pest control, pruning, weeding, and fire. The project proponent has a special pest control team, with demonstrated experience. The auditor verified procedures implemented to identify and control pests, as well as training activities for relevant personnel. Each FMU has a register documenting these activities. GPS units are used to monitor project boundaries, as confirmed during verification. The auditor visited six landmarks, in the FMU: Runamula, Centro, Chicua, Bermudas, Carrizal, Urcututo and two regeneration areas. The project proponent provided maps of the actual boundary which were found to be consistent with landmarks visited by the auditor.

Is the project implementation in line with the PD?; ref 2, 3; verification_findings Yes, a summary description is provided in the MR PD (page 81) establishes the accumulated GHG removals by sinks until 2011. PD establishes that species to be planted are Caoba (Swietenia macrophylla) Tahuari (Tabebuia serratifolia), Marupa (Simarouba amara) and Shihuahuaco (Dipterix odorata); and that restoration of degraded soils will be facilitated initially through the planting of Guaba trees (Inga edulis). MR includes Capirona (Calycophyllum sp.) in the list of species to be reforested and Erytrina (Erythrina sp.) in the list of species used for restoration purposes. PD establishes a total reforestation area of 740 ha and a total area of 179.7 ha where natural regeneration of forest will be facilitated through integrated weed management, control of grazing and prevention of fires. MR states that the project will reforest in total 787.95 ha, and additionally 124 ha of natural regeneration area are being recovered as a consequence of the project Some extent of the area previously designed for Assisted Natural Regeneration was used for plantation, thus the extent of the area for direct planting has increased. Trees have successfully been established, as can be seen in section 1.9. A recent evaluation (July 2008) took place demonstrating plantation success. Height, stem diameter, and mortality rates will be used to adjust the modeled growth rates used in the model to estimate carbon sequesteredeach year. survey was recently conducted to evaluate the growth and mortality rate of pilot plantation. The results indicate that the plantation has been established successfully considering both these criteria. After 3 years of guaba and 2 years of timber wood species establishment, the average mortality rate is 4% for the guaba and 1% for the timber wood species. FM-BAM has a highly skilled group of Peruvian foresters working at the reforestation site. Expert forestry consultants have been consulting on the forestry planting regime and management, as well as relevant literature sources consulted. This pilot area is not included within the carbon project boundaries

carbon_pools Soil organic carbon; selected_yes/no No; justification_/_explanation_of_choice As the lands to be planted are degraded and degrading or in a low-level steady state, and comply with the applicability conditions set in A/R Methodological tool “Procedure to determine when accounting of the soil organic carbon pool may be conservatively neglected in CDM A/R project activities”42 as follow: a) The lands to be planted are not organic soils (e.g., peat- lands), or wetlands; b) The rate of loss of carbon stocks in mineral soils due to erosion within the project boundary is not be permanently increased above baseline rates by the proposed ARR project activity43. c) Fine litter (woody twigs less than 2mm diameter, bark and leaves) will not be collected and removed. risk_factor Risk of rising land opportunity costs that cause reversal of sequestration and/or protection; risk_rating Low; campo_verde_project There is always a risk that alternative economic activities will raise land opportunity costs and threaten reversal of sequestration in a project area. This risk, however, is mitigated in several ways in the Campo Verde project. The project is on freehold land 1. owned by the project developer, SFM- BAM. This enables the project management to take a long-term perspective on the underlying business opportunity. The project’s management has 2. specifically targeted this land for reforestation. The lands in the surrounding area currently support little economic activity, apart from low-density cattle grazing and subsistence agriculture. Degradation trends across the project area show that the current state of the lands is likely to persist in its current condition as it has done since the 1980’s. Large scale, commercial cattle ranching was abandoned many years ago due to the economic downturn and terrorist activity, and was not re-established due to the degraded state of the lands and hence the prospect of low returns in the future.

findings_from_verification_field_audit A At validation the project proponent had to make a number of assumptions for the survival rate, growth and yield, and productivity of the proposed project. This information is detailed in Section 1.9 of the PD. s this verification audit relies on monitoring data that was actually collected in the field, there are limited assumptions that must be relied on. Assumptions around baseline carbon sequestration in the project area are conservative and accurate and were confirmed in the initial validation. Current carbon sequestration is based on verified growth, survival and yield data.

risk_factor Risk of social instability; campo_verde_project W S T T There has been no wide-spread social unrest in Peru in the recent past. This area is relatively rural and has not experienced any unrest since the Shining Path period. FM-BAM has made a commitment toward working directly with the surrounding local communities and local government and has a strong positive relationship with the major stakeholders. here were no people living within the boundaries of the project prior to the start of project activities and all the project land is privately owned. here were four families living outside the project area, but within the SFM-BAM property at the start of the project. These families were aware they were living on SFM- BAM land and were moved to existing lands covered by pasture and cropland.20 hile recent national political issues concerning the rights of indigenous people have affected the communities of the Ucayali region, to this date violent protests and confrontations between groups have not occurred nor has the region observed any national strike. In the Ucayali region political dissent is expressed in the form of peaceful marches and meetings. 21

A recent evaluation (July 2008) took place demonstrating plantation success. Height, stem diameter, and mortality rates will be used to adjust the modeled growth rates used in the model to estimate carbon tones captured per year. recent survey was recently conducted to evaluate the growth and mortality rate of the pilot plantation.
